metadata.title: What should virologists be teaching their students?
metadata.author: Philip P. Mortimer
metadata.abstract: In all these instances goals can only be achieved if Society's leaders are persuaded that the benefits are desirable, cost-effective and, as appropriate, urgent. The academic virologist must therefore regard clinical and public health advocacy as at least as important as dwelling upon his/her particular loci of research, and they must offer their students a broad grasp of the ecology of virus infections. For almost all of their students this will be more important than the minutiae of virus genomics. The students of today are the clinical decisiontakers of tomorrow, and they need to understand the interface between virus pathogens and humans.

introduction: In this the 21st century, medical virology can be said to have entered its post-modern phase; but what is implied by that? In 1900, viruses were an unopened book with no direct evidence of their existence. Now, however, it is possible to read a virus genome from beginning to end, and with next generation sequencing (NGS) it is possible to do so almost instantaneously. At the same time, virological diagnosis has become more precise, and the immunological memory of virus infections has been made sharper than ever. Suppression and cure of virus infections is beginning to be realised, spread of important viral pathogens is being interrupted, and the eradication of a few of them has largely been realised if not universally so.

In all these instances goals can only be achieved if Society's leaders are persuaded that the benefits are desirable, cost-effective and, as appropriate, urgent. The academic virologist must therefore regard clinical and public health advocacy as at least as important as dwelling upon his/her particular loci of research, and they must offer their students a broad grasp of the ecology of virus infections. For almost all of their students this will be more important than the minutiae of virus genomics. The students of today are the clinical decisiontakers of tomorrow, and they need to understand the interface between virus pathogens and humans.

summary: In this the 21st century, medical virology can be said to have entered its post-modern phase; but what is implied by that? In 1900, viruses were an unopened book with no direct evidence of their existence.

The academic virologist must regard clinical and public health advocacy as at least as important as dwelling upon his/her particular loci of research, and they must offer their students a broad grasp of the ecology of virus infections.
The students of today are the clinical decisiontakers of tomorrow, and they need to understand the interface between virus pathogens and humans.
An antiviral for influenza is only likely to be effective if part of very timely treatment, or prophylactically as soon as an exposure is recognised.

Health authorities worldwide are struggling to persuade at-risk groups and health workers to accept yearly influenza vaccination; the vaccine on offer is one scarcely different from that which first came into use 70 years ago and is not always effective.
It would be helpful to more narrowly define the incubation periods of virus infections avoiding making them impractically wide, as well as identifying when infectiousness is likely to be greatest.

For the otherwise mortal Ebola infection, antiviral combinations and vaccine have made intensive care and treatment a realistic approach even in the poorly resourced and politically uncertain environments where that virus has recently been, or still is, active.[4,5]

Tests for papilloma virus types 16/18 have become accepted as the earliest prophylactic tool in human cervical cancer prevention, and teenage immunisation promises to eliminate these high risk infections.
Infant hepatitis B virus infection mediates liver cancer: how best, to identify and reach the appropriate target groups and vaccinate them?6

None of this catalogue of virological problems needs rocket science to explain them or respond to them; but in the few weeks that virologists are allotted to educate medical and other students the emphasis must be on virus ecology.

The means of virus exposure, susceptibility, and transmissibility; of virus treatment and prophylaxis; and of scope for control of virus spread and even elimination: these are the knowledge base needed by future decision-takers, whether to be used at the bedside or in the contexts of national and international public health.
